stories.title: Letcture Notes for Tim Roughgarden's (Columbia Prof) Course on Blockchains
Apple drops iOS Private Relay feature for users in Russia

stories.text:
Hi, long time Linux user here. I've been using Firejail for years to isolate apps from my ~/Documents and web browser data, so that there's a smaller risk of downloaded binaries like Signal and Steam accessing my private data.

Now I'm thinking of getting a Macbook for the nicer creature comforts. I notice that MacOS apps installed outside the app store have full access to ~/Library, which means things like Signal and Steam can freely poke around my web browser cookie files. This seems bad to me.

I think these are the options, and none of them work very. Wonder if anyone has better suggestions:

1. sandbox-exec [1]: Poorly documented and deprecated. Might go away in upcoming releases of MacOS.

2. Create separate user accounts and `sudo su` as them, then execute the binary. This kind of works but some apps give strange results. Firefox seems to lanuch OK, but I can't run steam this way. I can download the dmg, run `xattr -d com.apple.quarantine /path/Steam.dmg` then run it, the auto updater shows up, and then it closes itself without launching the store UI. If I double click as the `sudo`ed account normally, it runs fine.

Also apps launched with `sudo` don't show up when I run the app switcher with Command-Tab, not sure why.

[1] https://jmmv.dev/2019/11/macos-sandbox-exec.html
stories.title: How to isolate apps from private data in macOS?
